DP123B – Global Access Manager: Workshop


Monday, November 12

3:25 pm – 4:10 pm


Karin Burns


  • Karin Burns is currently a Senior Solution Consultant for ONESOURCE. She has been with Thomson Reuters for over 10 years, having held various roles on the services team and helping our global regions adopt new technology.

  • Prior to Thomson Reuters Karin spent a few years at KPMG in which she worked on Federal and State compliance for corporations, partnerships and individuals. In addition Karin spent a few years working internally in a tax department. In that role she prepared the provision, compliance, sales and use and property taxes and implemented TaxStream.

  • Karin has an undergraduate degree in Accounting and a Master of Taxation both from Arizona State University.



    Confidential and Proprietary


    Objectives

    Upon completion, attendees will be able to select and apply the steps required for the system to calculate and post data in the web-based Global Access module of ONESOURCE Tax Provision.


    Agenda


  • Overview

  • ONESOURCE platform Administration Setup

  • ONESOURCE Tax Provision Administration Setup

  • Global Access Administration Setup

  • Data Entry Page and Process Overview

  • Generating Reports


    Confidential and Proprietary


    Overview




    5


    What Is Global Access?

  • An application designed to simplify the provision data entry process while also serving as a robust reporting engine

  • Utilizes a common database



    Benefits of Using Global Access?

  • Multiple jurisdiction data collection

  • Automatic consolidation

  • Real time data entry

  • Simultaneous access for multiple users

  • Security controls

  • Sign-off feature


    ONESOURCE platform Administration Setup




    8


    Assigning Users to Global Access

  • Sign into platform and Select Administration




    Assigning Users to Global Access

  • Edit the Available Users as appropriate



    Assigning Users to Global Access

  • Select “Global Access” to assign the User to Global Access

    Confidential and Proprietary

  • Select “Sign-Off Permissions”


    Assigning Users to Global Access

  • Select the appropriate sign off level for the user

  • Select Back to Tax Provision, scroll down to click “Next”

  • Review product licenses and click “Done”



    Confidential and Proprietary


    ONESOURCE Tax Provision Administration Setup




    13


    User Assignments

  • To Manage Users that have already been created in platform:

  • Click on Users, from the Manage Users folder within the System folder within Administration


    User Assignments

  • Specific Datasets, Units, SubConsolidations, and Global Access Roles by Unit can be assigned to specific Users in Administration




    User Role Assignments

  • Administrators can replicate tax department roles by creating User Roles

    • Users are assigned to specific User Roles

    • User Roles are then assigned access rights, or permissions, to certain pages within the application, customizing the view of the application for each User

      Most of the Global Access “switches” can be assigned in this area of the application

      Menu Configuration files can still be created for Global Access and will take precedence over assignments made in this area of the application


      User Role Assignments

      The application can have multiple User Roles

      A User can be assigned to only 1 User Role at a time


      User Group Assignments

  • Administrators can add and remove Permissions from specific User Roles using the Permissions tab in this area of the application



    Unit Assignments

    ONESOURCE Tax Provision Components, listed below, must be assigned to each Unit for them to be available to Users within the Global Access application

    • After Tax Temporary Differences

    • Trial Balance Accounts

    • Jurisdictions

    • Liability Transactions

    • NOL Temporary Differences

    • Permanent Differences

    • Tax Adjustments

    • Temporary Differences

    • Unit PTBI Details

    • Any corresponding Jurisdiction or State Components


      Dataset Management

      Confidential and Proprietary

      Datasets must be “published” to Global Access in order for them to be available within Global Access


      Dataset Management “Column Types”

    • yeprov: Regular Provision dataset

    • yeprovgs: GAAP to Stat dataset

    • retprov: Regular Return to Provision dataset

    • retprovgs: Return to Provision GAAP to Stat dataset

    • reporting: Reporting dataset

    • Q1/Q2/Q3_forecast: Interim Forecast dataset

    • Q1/Q2/Q3_actual: Interim Actual dataset



      Confidential and Proprietary


      Global Access Administration Setup




      22

      Sign Off Sequence



      Confidential and Proprietary

      Confidential and Proprietary

The Manage Questionnaires page allows the administrator to create multiple questionnaires and assign them to specific datasets



Manage Questionnaire and Checklist

The Checklists are similar to questionnaires. However a checklist can be configured for various statuses such as Incomplete (#1), Prepared (#2), etc.

  • Checklist codes use the following coding system: ‘cl_XXXX_#’

Manage Questionnaire and Checklist

Manage User Permissions

Confidential and Proprietary

The Manage User Permissions page allows the administrator to Manage the access rights or Permissions within the application





Data Entry Page and Process Overview




31


General Information

The application is fully configurable by the Global Access Administrator based each licensee’s needs; as such, different Users may have access to different items from within the application, which could include:

  • Legal entities or Units

  • Provision calculations or Datasets

  • Tax components, which include items such as permanent differences, temporary differences, tax adjustments, etc.

  • Global Access reports


    Various Data Entry Pages

    The Introduction Page will appear when the application is launched

  • This Page may include documents available for download

  • Contact information may be attached to the Corp. Tax Dept Contacts Link, which is on each Page of the application by uploading a global attachment with the code “Corp_Contacts”



    Various Data Entry Pages

    Users can also navigate directly to Pages and Areas within the application by clicking on links in the Menu Bar



    Various Data Entry Pages

    The Unit List Page will display the Units and Datasets that have been assigned to the User

  • The Unit’s status for the provision calculation is reflected in the respective Dataset column, following the Unit Code column



Various Data Entry Pages

The Unit Data Page may allow a User the ability to select other Units and Datasets




Various Data Entry Pages

Based upon the User’s Access Rights within the application, the Pre-Tax Book Income, or PTBI, Page allows a User to enter pre-tax book income or loss



Various Data Entry Pages

Data entry Pages generally also allow a User to Edit information within the application based upon the User’s Access Rights within the application


Various Data Entry Pages

Based upon the User’s Access Rights within the application, the Income Tax Rates Page allows a User to enter certain income tax



Various Data Entry Pages

Based upon the User’s Access Rights within the application, the Permanent Diffs Page allows a User to enter permanent differences between book and taxable income that will not reverse in the future

Confidential and Proprietary

– The Edit, Delete, Attach and Show Comment History icons function the same as explained in the Pre-Tax Book Income training slides


Various Data Entry Pages

Based upon the User’s Access Rights within the application, the Temporary Diffs Page allows a User to enter temporary differences between book and taxable income that will reverse in the future



Various Data Entry Pages

The Sign Off Page allows a User to indicate that the Unit’s data entry for that respective Dataset is complete and the User has signed off on the provision calculation

– Once a Unit is Signed Off as complete, it advances to the next Sign Off Role, the instructions no longer appear on each Page, and the Unit is generally Read Only to that User




Generating Reports




43


General Information

The application is fully configurable by the Global Access Administrator based each licensee’s needs; as such, different Users may have access to different items from within the application, which could include:

  • Legal entities or Units

  • Provision calculations or Datasets

  • Tax components, which include items such as permanent differences, temporary differences, tax adjustments, etc.

  • Global Access reports


    How to Generate Reports

    Access the Unit, from the Unit List Page, for which you wish to generate Reports and select the Report level


    How to Generate Reports

    Click the Report name you wish to generate from the Reports available to the User

  • The Reports are listed in the “Reports” area of the Menu Bar, positioned on the left side of the web page

    Once the Report is selected:

  • A Report Configuration Ribbon will display; this Ribbon has the same functionality as the ONESOURCE Tax Provision configuration options

  • The Ribbon allows the User to customize the Report based upon the available Reporting and Class Options


How to Generate Reports






How to Generate Reports

The Output Options include Run, Print, Save and Page Setup




Reports and Class Options

  • Users can customize their Reports by selecting the desired Report and Class Options from the available dropdown menus

    • Report Options vary from Report Ribbon to Report Ribbon

    • Not all Reports can be generated using Class Options

DP127B – Automation: NOLs, Valuation Allowance, AMT

Wednesday, November 14

1:05 pm – 2:00 pm


1


Linda Harrell


  • Linda is a Senior Training Specialist at Thomson Reuters responsible for development and delivery of training for many products including ONESOURCE Tax Provision, ONESOURCE Income Tax, integration and ONESOURCE DataFlow.

  • Previous positions during her twenty-two year tenure with Thomson Reuters include 1120 Support Manager and ONESOURCE Direct Representative.

  • Prior to joining Thomson Reuters, Linda held several corporate accounting positions at a closely held savings & loan in south Florida.

  • Linda holds a Bachelor’s of Business Administration in Accounting from Florida Atlantic University, is a Certified Public Accountant and a Chartered Global Management Accountant.


    Confidential and Proprietary

Confidential and Proprietary


NOLs - Federal




5


Enable Current Year NOL Automation

  • Manage Units | MORE | Other | Automation tab

  • This will create a Federal Only NOL – this selection will not affect the state calculation



    Functionality and Process

    • The current federal loss will move from the current provision to a deferred tax asset, i.e., an offsetting NOL deferred tax asset will be created to offset the current loss on the provision.

    • The reclass brings the federal taxable income to zero and will automatically adjust if income amounts change.

    • The reclass of the NOL from the provision calculation to the unit’s deferred balances report is accomplished via a posting to the temporary difference NOL_SYS.


      Example

  • In a current year, there is a taxable loss of $100,000



    Example

    Confidential and Proprietary

  • The Current Year Loss will be used to reduce tax in a future year. Therefore, it will be carried forward as an NOL temporary difference and a deferred tax asset




    Example

  • NOL Temp Difference Entry



    Example

  • The reclass of the federal current loss as presented on the Deferred Balances report




    Example

  • An NOL deferred tax asset will be set up to offset the federal current loss on the provision.




    Example

  • The user can control how much NOL is reclassed to a deferred tax asset, as well as how much NOL is utilized annually


    Example

  • If there is an annual NOL limitation (Sec 382), enter that amount in the box labeled Base NOL Allowance and 0% for NOL Allowance Rate.



    Example

  • The expiration year of the current year NOL is entered on the NOL Temp Differences screen.



    Prior Year NOLs

  • Prior Year NOLs are user-defined and created using the same coding convention used for the system-generated current year NOL, i.e., the NOL_SYS coding convention.

  • Example: In Administration, a NOL_SYS_2012 NOL Temp Diff is created.



    Prior Year NOLs

  • This NOL Temp Diff for 2012 is then added to a specific Unit with an appropriate Generated date, Expires date and Beginning Balance.




    Prior Year NOLs

  • The NOL Balances report will display the current year and prior year(s) NOLs



    Prior Year NOLs

  • The NOLs Expiration Report shows the final results of the automation and user entries



    Filing Groups




    20


    Definition and Process

  • Units grouped in a Filing Group will be considered as a single unit when applying automation rules. The resulting net attribute of the automation will be posted to the Parent unit.

  • Units grouped in a sub-consolidation will first be subjected to automation on a single unit basis and the results will be added with other units in the sub-consolidation.


    Confidential and Proprietary


    Set Filing Group Configurations

    Confidential and Proprietary


    Filing Parent is Unit JC99

  • Unit Properties






    Set Filing Group Configurations

    Confidential and Proprietary


    Unit LS99 is a Sub of Filing Parent Unit JC99

  • Unit Properties





    Disabled Automation

  • Automation will be disabled at the sub level. Any automation will be performed at the parent level.

  • The system will automatically calculate the NOL on the combined taxable income of all the subs and the parent



    Example




    NOLs - State




    26


    Enable NOL Automation

    • NOL Automation for states is activated via Manage Units - Jurisdictions



      After Apportionment Temp Diff Screen

    • The NOL will be input by the system on the State After App Temp Difference Screen

    • The system will post a reclass to create the NOL Temporary difference when the unit has a taxable loss or will draw down an available NOL Temporary Difference when the unit has taxable income.

    • After-App Temp Diffs are created in Administration


      After Apportionment Temp Diff Screen

    • These After-App Temp Diffs are then added to a specific Unit and State(s) with an appropriate Beginning Balance




      Confidential and Proprietary


      Valuation Allowance




      30


      Functionality and Process

    • Valuation Allowance amounts can be automatically posted for deferred tax assets, based on a predetermined percentage

    • Generated valuation allowances display as a contra asset in reports


      Functionality and Process

    • Enable Valuation Allowance Automation by checking the box on the Manage Units | MORE | Other | Automation tab



      Functionality and Process 3 Methods

      • Separate Attribute Basis (the default)

      • Aggregated Attribute Basis

      • Aggregated Attribute Post-Tax Basis


      Functionality and Process

    • Setting Dataset Parameters is required for full Valuation Allowance functionality

    • Parameter: VA_CALCTYPE

      0 - Activates the Separate basis 2 - Activates the Aggregate basis

      4 - Activates the Aggregate Post-Tax basis



    • Separate Attribute Basis (Default)

    • Separately determines the need for a valuation allowance for Temporary Differences, NOL Temp Differences and After Tax Temporary Differences groupings

    • When the balance for the Temporary Differences, NOL Temp Differences or After Tax Temporary Differences is an asset, the system will generate a valuation allowance to offset the specific type (Temp, NOL Temp, AT Temp)

    • Classification of current or noncurrent is based on the assets and liabilities generating the valuation allowance



      Separate Attribute Basis (Default)

    • Valuation Allowance Rate can be entered for each category: After Tax Temp Diff; NOL Temp Diff; Temp Diff



      Separate Attribute Basis (Default)

    • If balances for the Temporary Differences net to an asset, the system posts a valuation allowance




      Aggregated Attribute Basis

  • Combines the Temporary Differences, NOL Temp Differences and After Tax Temporary Differences balances to determine the need for a valuation allowance

  • When the combined balance for Temporary Differences, NOL Temp Differences and After Tax Temporary Differences is an asset, the system will generate a valuation allowance to offset

    It will order the VA first to the After Tax Temporary Difference, then to the NOL Temporary Difference and lastly to the Temporary Difference

    Current/Non-Current classification of Valuation Allowance items is calculated in compliance with ASC 740


    Aggregated Attribute Basis



    Aggregated Attribute Post-Tax Basis

  • Current Valuation Allowance Posting on both Pre & After Tax Basis in many scenarios can cause issues and incorrect postings

  • Under the aggregated method, the software solves first to identify where a unit or filing group has a Net Deferred Tax Asset position

  • If a DTA, it then Posts on a Pre-Tax Basis to NOLs & Temps and plugs the Ending Deferred Rate to achieve the correct after tax amount

  • This method can cause unexpected Ending Deferred Rates to post & in some cases does not create the correct After Tax Valuation Allowance on an after rate basis


    Aggregated Attribute Post-Tax Basis

  • Current Valuation Allowance Posting on both Pre & After Tax Basis in many scenarios can cause issues and incorrect postings



    Alternative Minimum Tax




    42


    Functionality and Process

  • Can be automatically calculated and posted based on entered adjustments and rates

  • The generated AMT posts as an After Tax Temporary Difference - Tax Basis with the adjustment code AMT_SYS

  • Enable AMT Automation by clicking the box in the Manage Units | MORE | Other | Automation tab



    Functionality and Process

  • The calculation for the AMT will compute based on:

    • AMT Adjustments (Preference Items)

    • AMT Rate

    • AMT After Tax Adjustments (Foreign Tax Credits)

    • AMT NOL Carryover Balance entered




    Functionality and Process

  • Automation is determined by a Reporting Currency or Local Currency approach

  • A system parameter setting determines which approach is used

  • However, the approach can also be designated on a dataset-by-dataset basis with a dataset parameter

  • An AMT Estimator Report is available, at the filing group level, within the Legacy reporting capability


    Functionality and Process

  • AMT Local Currency Approach has more limited functionality than the Reporting Currency approach. It is not recommended.

  • All units in a filing group must have the same currency for the calculation to be logical

  • Net Operating Losses for both regular tax and AMT are not considered separately in the calculation

  • Consider using the AMT Reporting Currency approach because it considers both regular and AMT NOLs in the calculation


    Functionality and Process

  • AMT Reporting Currency Approach expands the Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) calculation.

    • There is the ability to enter and consider the AMT Net Operating Loss Carryover Balance

    • AMT is computed using the unit's data in reporting currency

    • AMT is posted to the parent unit by converting from reporting currency to the parent unit's local currency

  • AMT Liability or AMT Recapture is automatically posted to the After Tax Temporary Difference with the adjustment code AMT_SYS


    Example



    Example

  • The AMT Estimator Report displays in Reporting Currency under the Filing Group Reports (in the Reporting (Legacy) folder.

  • Regular Tax Calculation starts with Federal Tax Current from the Tax Provision Report and then considers the impact of Foreign Tax Credits from either Cash Tax Adjustments or user-designated After Tax Temporary Difference activity to arrive at an Adjusted Cash Provision

  • Alternative Tax Calculation starts with Federal Taxable Income (Pre-NOL) from the Tax Provision Report and then adds back any entered AMT preference items. The result is then offset up to 90% with the AMT NOL to arrive at Alternative Minimum Taxable Income that is rate effected by the AMT rate to arrive at the AMT (pre credits)

  • It then considers any entered AMT Foreign Tax Credits to arrive at the Tentative Minimum Tax


    Example

  • Note: This is a version 2014.1 Legacy report



    Example

  • AMT Liability (Recapture), the Tentative Minimum Tax, is compared with the Adjusted Cash Provision to determine if there is an AMT Liability or potential Recapture of an AMT carryover from prior years.

  • If the Tentative Minimum Tax is greater than the Adjusted Cash Provision, the system posts that amount to the Parent Unit in the Filing Group as activity in the After Tax Temporary Difference section with the adjustment code AMT_SYS

  • If the Tentative Minimum Tax is less than the Adjusted Cash Provision, the system looks to the beginning balance of the After Tax Temporary Difference with the adjustment code AMT_SYS in the filing group's parent unit beginning balance; to the extent there is a balance, it will recapture that amount in activity


    Example

  • Note: This is a version 2014.1 screen display




Thank You

    Estimated Payments Overview




    5


    Functionality

  • Calculates both Federal and State Estimated Payments

  • Provides efficiency by allowing the reuse of data from

    • ONESOURCE Income Tax

    • ONESOURCE Tax Provision

    • ONESOURCE State Apportionment


      Functionality

  • Provides current tax law content

  • Calculates extension and estimated payments by jurisdiction/filing group

  • Populates vouchers for push-button printing

  • Pushes payments back to ONESOURCE Income Tax, ONESOURCE Tax Provision and ONESOURCE Calendar




Tax Provision and Estimated Payments Process Design



10


Tax Provision and Estimated Payments Process Design


Six objectives of the process design review

  1. Determine data components in ONESOURCE Tax Provision datasets that can be used to calculate extensions and estimates within Estimated Payments

  2. For data that will not come from ONESOURCE Tax Provision, determine the source and format of the data and best method for using the data within Estimated Payments

  3. Create workpapers for supplementary data/calculations to be imported into Estimated Payments

  4. Document future process using Estimated Payments

  5. Create prior quarter recreation and testing plan

  6. Create training and rollout plan

DP132 - General Ledger Manager Overview

Tuesday, November 13

10:35 am – 11:30 am


1


Jake Mattern, CPA


  • Jake is a member of the ONESOURCE Solution Consultant Team and has been with Thomson Reuters for 1 year.

  • Previously, Jake worked as a tax professional for 10 years. He spent 3 years in public accounting, and approximately 8 years in a corporate tax department, where he acquired hands- on experience with ONESOURCE products. Jake was most recently a Tax Manager, where one of his main focuses was on process improvement initiatives, specifically around the tax provision and tax compliance processes.

  • Jake has a BS in Accounting and Business, with a concentration in Management Information Systems and is a licensed CPA in the State of North Carolina.



Confidential and Proprietary


Objective

Upon completion, attendees will be able to recognize the fundamental features and functionality of the General Ledger Manager tool and determine the efficiencies it provides for preparing trial balance data.


Agenda


  • Introduction


  • Setup


  • Import


  • Create


  • Review


  • Workpapers


    Confidential and Proprietary


    Introduction




    6


    Overview

  • General Ledger Manager is a universal entry point for trial balances into the ONESOURCE Platform. It allows trial balances from multiple general ledger systems and/or Charts of Accounts to quickly be converted into a standardized format and also provides a central repository for this data.

    • Capture and preserve original source data

    • Compare and review trial balance versions

    • Combine branch/division trial balances into legal entity trial balances

    • Integration with other Solutions on the ONESOURCE Platform


      Overview

  • Key Concept

    • Master Charts of Accounts

      • Standardize and tax sensitize Trial Balance data for use by the entire Tax Department

      • Minimize administration and maintenance redundancies

      • Master chart can be used for other solutions on the ONESOURCE Platform

    • Master Trial Balances

      • Create automation to pull balances directly from your General Ledger systems

      • Utilize data for tax return filings, global tax provisions, and all other tax processes fostering efficiencies and enabling uniformity

      • Data can be pulled into DataFlow templates for use in furthering automating your provision and return processes


Administrator Role vs. User Role



Setup




10


Setup Menu Items


Setup Menu Items – Create Import Layouts

  • Create a data import layout for each uniquely formatted trial balance data file that will be upload to General Ledger Manager, generally by the User

    • Format and layout characteristics of a trial balance file are entered into each import layout, for example:

      • File format (xlsx, csv, etc.)

      • Starting row of its data

      • The column letters/numbers for the required trial balance data fields

  • An import layout will be assigned to each chart of accounts (created in the next step)


    Setup Menu Items – Create Import Layouts

  • Example Trial Balance File




    Setup Menu Items – Create Import Layouts



    Setup Menu Items – Create Import Layouts



    Setup Menu Items – Create Chart of Accounts


  • Establish a chart for each unique account numbering structure used within your enterprise

    • Chart includes Account Numbers & Descriptions

  • Assign import layout to the Chart of Accounts after creation


    Setup Menu Items – Create Chart of Accounts

  • Example SAP Chart



    Setup Menu Items – Create Chart of Accounts

  • Example SAP Chart



    Setup Menu Items – Create Chart of Accounts

  • Add accounts manually to the chart



    Setup Menu Items – Create Chart of Accounts

  • Import accounts



    Setup Menu Items – Create Master Chart of Accounts

  • The Master Chart of Accounts is the framework upon which the standardized Master Trial Balances are created

  • Consists of Master Account Number, Description, TRC & TCC

  • Master charts of accounts created here can also be used in ONESOURCE Income Tax and ONESOURCE Provision


    Setup Menu Items – Create Master Chart of Accounts

  • Creating a master chart is a 2-step process

    • Step 1 – Define master account numbers and descriptions

    • Step 2 – Map master account numbers to Tax Return Codes(TRC) & Tax Combination Codes(TCC)


      Setup Menu Items – Create Master Chart of Accounts

  • Step 1 – Define master account numbers and descriptions




    Setup Menu Items – Create Master Chart of Accounts

  • Step 2 – Map master account numbers to Tax Return Codes (TRC’s) & Tax Combination Codes (TCC’s)

    • In ONESOURCE Income Tax, system-defined TRCs are used to map individual account balances from a company’s general ledger to specific lines on the tax return

    • To ensure that account balances are transferred to the appropriate area of the tax return, every account in a company’s master chart of accounts must be assigned to a valid TRC

    • In ONESOURCE Tax Provision, TRCs and TCCs are used to consolidate Subline accounts



      Setup Menu Items – Reporting Units

  • Create reporting units that are expected to be used in the Trial Balance files that will be uploaded to General Ledger Manager

  • Reporting units can be an entity, cost center, department, division, business unit, line of business, etc. It typically represents the lowest level of detail on which data is tracked.

  • Corresponding Units can be created in ONESOURCE Provision and/or ONESOURCE Income Tax


    Setup Menu Items – Reporting Units




    Setup Menu Items – Account Maps

  • Each Chart of Accounts requires mapping to the Master Chart of Accounts




    Setup Menu Items – Account Maps

  • Mapping of accounts to the Master Chart can be done either manually, through a drag and drop process, or via an electronic import of information.




    Setup Menu Items – Reporting Unit Rollups

  • Reporting Unit Rollups are used to control the relationship between General Ledger Manager reporting units and ONESOURCE Tax Provision Units and ONESOURCE Income Tax Entities

    • Can be used to combine Trial Balances from Cost Centers, Departments, divisions, etc.

  • Can have multiple rollups for each year



    Setup Menu Items – Rollover

    Confidential and Proprietary

  • Save time and effort by rolling the Charts of Accounts, Master Chart of Accounts, Account Maps & Reporting Unit Rollups to the following year.


    Import




    31


    Create Trial Balance Data Import File

  • The Trial Balance import file must contain:

    • Reporting Unit / Entity Code

    • General Ledger Account Code

    • Ending Balances

    • Beginning Balances are optional


      Create Trial Balance Data Import File

  • The Trial Balance data can only be for one (1) time period

    • Month, Year, or Year-to-Date

  • If blank lines / rows are present in the data file the import will stop importing at the blank line / row

  • Must not have any unknown account codes


    Add Trial Balance Data Import File to Queue

  • Browse to and select a data file

    • Select Data Type, either Year, Month, or To Date

    • Select Date / Year



      Add Trial Balance Data Import File to Queue

  • System will display a preview of the data in the file

  • Click Next



    Add Trial Balance Data Import File to Queue

  • Select a chart of accounts that will receive the $$ amounts in the Excel data file

  • Once selected, click Next




    Add Trial Balance Data Import File to Queue

  • Select an import format

  • Click Add to Queue



    General Ledger Manager Connect

  • It is a licensed add-on to General Ledger Manager

  • Enables General Ledger Manager to monitor a folder in the customer’s environment where their ERP or General Ledger System can save extracts of trial balance data

    • As files are added to the folder (with file names that General Ledger Manager has been configured to recognize), the files will automatically be populated in the Import Queue in General Ledger Manager




      Import Trial Balance Data File

  • Confirm a Format Validation of “Valid”

  • Enable check box next to the file name

  • Click Import




    Import Trial Balance Data File

  • If account data exists in the data import file but the chart of accounts selected for the import does not contain one (1) or more of those accounts, the system will display error messages

  • These unknown accounts need to be added to the appropriate Chart of Accounts and then mapped to the Master Chart in the Account Maps



    Import Trial Balance Data File

  • If no errors occurred with the import, click Review the imported trial balances




    Import Trial Balance Data File

  • All account balances will be displayed



    Adjustments to Account Balances

  • Adjustments can be manually entered or imported



    Adjustments to Account Balances

  • Click View / Edit to enter Notes for the adjustment



    Adjustments to Account Balances

  • Adjustment sum must equal zero (0)




    Compare & Review

  • Quickly compare revised trial balances against the previous versions to determine the account balances that have been modified


    Compare & Review

  • Choose Revised File and then Select Compare & Review



    Compare & Review

  • Select previous version and then select review comparison results



    Compare & Review

  • The resulting file provides you with any accounts added, edited or deleted.

  • Side by side file comparison highlights accounts that have changed

  • File can be exported and saved as part of your documentation

60


Data Management Tools

  • The goal of ONESOURCE Workpapers is to provide a single data management tool for use with all ONESOURCE applications

  • You can leverage your trial balance data within ONESOURCE Workpapers from ONESOURCE General Ledger Manager to automate your tax calculations and tax processes



    GET: Retrieve data from General Ledger Manager and post to a Workpaper

  • GET individual GL account details from General Ledger Manager and pull it down into your Excel- based processes and calculations to create automation in your tax processes.



    Range Mapping

  • GET your entire trial balance, pull it down into your Excel-based processes and calculations to create automation in your tax processes.

Nick Guarro

    Objectives

    Upon completion, attendees will be able to identify the general concepts of Version 2016’s flow-through functionality and determine the best use cases for this functionality.


    Agenda


  • Overview and Terminology

  • Configuration and Data Entry

  • Use Cases


    Overview and Terminology




    5


    Flow-Through

  • Provides an easy-to-use interface to transfer data entry values and/or calculated values from source (e.g. Partnership) units to target (e.g. Partner) units

  • Designed to assist with the following data flow automations:

    • Partnerships

    • CFCs

    • Branches

    • Hybrid Entities

    • Elimination Companies


      Flow-Through

  • Iterative (repetitive) Calculation

    • Triggered manually or upon running reports

    • Designed to be recalculated when source unit data is modified

    • Generates consistent and repeatable results

    • Handles multiple source/target relationships


      Flow-Through

  • To enable Flow-Through, an appropriate License Code and License Key are required

  • Administrators can enter this information by selecting the “Administration” area and clicking Administration | System | Manage Licenses


    Confidential and Proprietary

    Enable Flow-Through within Administration

Flow-Through Profiles

  • Determine how data will transfer – think of these like partnership agreements, ownership agreements, etc.

  • Choose to transfer gross amounts (PTBI, perms, temps) or net adjustments (Federal Current Tax Expense, State Deferred Tax Expense, etc).

  • Create an unlimited number of profiles

  • Used only in class datasets

    Flow-Through Profiles

  • To create select My Datasets| “Selected Dataset” | More | Flow-Through Profiles

    Guerrant, Savita (Tax&Accounting), 9/26/2017


    Flow-Through Profiles

  • Click the “+” button to add a profile

  • On the General Tab, type the “Profile Description” to add more details

  • For Data Movement choose “Gross Balances” or “Net Adjustments”

  • Jurisdictions

    • Check Federal

    • Click State to transfer the State Only modifications

      • This option is not available when you select gross balances – source units and target units may have different states


        Flow-Through Profiles



        Flow-Through Profiles

  • Select applicable source class (or classes), target class, and elimination class to appropriately classify data for calculation and reporting purposes


    Confidential and Proprietary

    17


    Flow-Through Profiles

  • If using a “Gross Balances” profile, users can select how items of income or loss will be allocated

  • Multiple options for allocating include:

    • ALL – allocate all items under category to a particular line item (i.e. all child level permanent differences allocated to parent as one permanent difference (i.e. Income/Loss from Flow- Through)

    • SELECTED – allocate selected items under category to selected line items

    • ALL EXCEPT – allocate all items except selected items under category to user defined line items


      Flow-Through Profiles – Component Selection



      Flow-Through Profiles – Net Adjustments



      Flow-Through Profiles

  • To assign a new Flow-Through Profile

    • Select My Datasets| Units | More| and then Properties



      Flow-Through Profiles

  • Select Flow-through and then Flow-Through Target or Source to assign units

  • Select the Target Unit (Source Unit), and Profile

  • The same profile can be assigned to multiple target units

  • Define the Factor percentage to be allocated to the Flow-Through profile

  • Select the Create Auto Elim option and add Profile Comment, if necessary


    Flow-Through Profiles



    Flow-Through Profiles

  • Data Transfer – Automatic

    • Select Administration and then System

    • Select Manage Configurations and then Advanced Functionality

    • Select Flow-Through options to transfer data

      • Select Yes for the parameter Automatically Calculate Flow-Through Factors

        – This option allows the application to transfer data upon Refresh of the Review and Edit screen or running reports


        Flow-Through Profiles – Data Transfer (Automatic)


        Confidential and Proprietary


        Flow-Through Profiles

  • Data Transfer – Manual

    • Select My Datasets | Calculator

    • Click Calculate Flow-Through Factor Results to transfer data from the source to the target unit


    • A message appears

      • "Are you sure you would like to calculate unit factor results? WARNING: This will erase all existing Flow- Through data before calculating the new results.”

    • Click Yes to calculate the Flow-Through


      Flow-Through Profiles – Data Transfer (Manual)



      Flow-Through Profiles

  • Data Source History

    • Used as an audit trail to review system calculated movement between entities

    • Will show summarized and detailed results and source data

    • Select Data Input | Federal | Permanent Diffs – Tax Basis

    Sabre Corporation

  • Sabre is a leading travel technology company. Sabre connects people and places with technology that reimagines the business of travel.

Sabre Tax Department

  • Responsible for global tax provision and all tax filings

KPIs from v2016 OTP Implementation


Risk reduction with expanded reporting options

  • Increased visibility into ETR drivers using classes; ability to see separate components of provision

  • Multi-Year Plan (over 2 years), Plan, and Current Year provision all on same platform

  • Efficiency gained during Interim provision due to preparation on familiar platform


    Added Transparency

  • Better flux analysis with dataset comparison; year over year, quarter over quarter

  • Ability to separately call out discretes and move between GAAP and NonGAAP environments

  • Consolidated reporting in one tool and dataset


    Shorter turn-around time between GAAP ETR and NonGAAP ETR

  • Reduced turn-around from 2 days to 4 hours at year-end

  • Now able to analyze and update NonGAAP ETR each quarter


Reasons for Upgrading from v2014 to v2016

  • Streamline and improve the interim process using an interim focused implementation

  • Maximize transparency using increased functionality of workpapers and classes/subclasses

  • Recode all OTP unit codes to align with new ERP GL Company Codes

  • Transition from tags to classes/subclasses more efficiently

  • Create one training to roll out globally

  • Utilize new user-friendly OTP interface


    Implementation Goals

    • Reduce risk related to provision calculations

    • Eliminate redundancies/inefficiencies between GAAP and NonGAAP environments

    • Standardize the interim and year-end processes across all jurisdictions

    • Maintain one platform for Interim and Year-End reporting

    • Calculate and retain Multi-Year Plan, Current Year Plan, and Forecast in same location

    • Gain flexibility through classes to further breakout components of the provision

    • Provide consistent, easy to review/audit workpapers

    • Utilize OTP reports for flux analysis


      Biggest Challenges

    • Training all users on the new workpapers, processes, and system

      • Excel Add-In, Data Import, Workpapers

    • Implementing a new environment – unresolved bugs/issues

    • Allocating the time and resources necessary to implement new version/processes

      • Dual processing

      • Transition period

    • Adjusting to new data entry screens and interface


      Lessons learned – advice for others

    • Assign designated implementation team to ensure project finishes on time and with least amount of interruption to all team members

    • Involve OTP expert for assistance in implementation

      • Insight into best practices

    • Seek feedback and involvement from designated OTP users

    • Reproduce prior datasets and work through any differences

    • Train two master admins simultaneously to ensure coverage

    • Consider training backup admins and use of “super users” as well


    • Interim, Hard-Close, and Year-End

    • Forecast, Current Year Plan and Multi-Year Plan, Cash Tax Forecast support

    • GAAP and NonGAAP calculations

    • Separate reporting for discretes versus AETR for Interim

    • Class functionality (allows for better visibility into separate components of provision)

      • Continuing Operations versus Discontinued Operations

      • Return to Provision

      • FIN 48

      • Discretes


Classes/subclasses provide more depth and better options for reporting and analyzing provision calculations.

  • Allows users to group and sort data easily (flexible reporting)

  • Provides additional controls for data entry – restricted entry, unassigned column

  • Adds reporting options and ability to break out components of provision

    • Continuing Ops versus Disc Ops

    • AETR versus Discretes

    • FIN 48 Total Provision


Do not use classes to identify “how” the data got into the system (manual, excel add-in, import, etc).

Confidential and Proprietary


Full Year Reporting - Datasets




5


Two methods generally used to create datasets:

  • Dataset Merge Method

    • Combine individual stand-alone datasets for each quarter by using the software’s dataset merge functionality

  • Year to Date (YTD) Dataset Method

    • Create a copy of the Q1 dataset and layer on changes for subsequent quarters


      Method 1 – Dataset Merge

  • Used to merge multiple datasets into one Full Year (FY) dataset

    • (ex. Q1, Q2, Q3 & Q4)


  • Located on the My UTP tab


  • A Reporting Dataset must be created first to use this functionality

    • This can be done in the Admin Center


      Method 1 – Dataset Merge

  • STEP 1 – Create a Reporting Dataset

    • Select Reporting Datasets from the drop-down menu in the Datasets & Reporting Datasets tab in the Admin Center


    • Click on Add in the lower left hand corner of the screen

    • Name the new dataset.

      • Ex. ‘2017 Full Year’


        Method 1 – Dataset Merge

  • STEP 2 – Assign Existing Datasets

    • In the Datasets & Reporting Datasets tab, select Assignments from the drop-down menu

    • Select the Reporting Dataset that was just created

    • Select the first dataset to include in the merged dataset by clicking on it

      • Ex. Q1 2017

      • It will highlight in blue




        Method 1 – Dataset Merge

  • STEP 2 – Assign Existing Datasets

    • Click on Save Assignment

    • The application will now display all datasets that are available to be added, based on the fiscal period

      • In the example below, all Q2 datasets will now appear

    • Select the next dataset to add

      • Repeat this process until all 4 quarters are selected


        Method 1 – Dataset Merge

  • STEP 3 – Merge Multiple Datasets into a Full Year

    • Make sure you are currently in one of the datasets that is being merged via the Settings tab

    • Click on Dataset Merge on the My UTP tab

      • Choose the Reporting Dataset that was just created

      • Enter the Fiscal Period as Full Year

      • Enter the Weighted Avg. Rate

      • Name the New Dataset

        • Can be similar to the reporting dataset name

      • Click Merge


        Method 1 – Dataset Merge

  • STEP 3 – Merge Multiple Datasets into a Full Year

    • In the Resulting Dataset

      • The Beginning balances come from the first dataset

      • The Ending Balances come from the last dataset

        • Ex. Q1 & Q4


          Method 2 – YTD Datasets

  • Alternative method to using the dataset merge functionality

    • Advantage – Easier to set up

    • Disadvantage – Can not view quarterly stand-alone alone datasets


      Method 2 – YTD Datasets

  • STEP 1

    • At the end of Q1, make a copy of the Q1 dataset

      • (As opposed to rolling it over to Q2)

    • Set the Fiscal Period as 2Q YTD


      Method 2 – YTD Datasets

  • STEP 2

    • Add Q2 Activity to the new dataset

    • The resulting dataset will have

      • The Q1 beginning balances

      • The Q2 ending balances

    • Repeat the process for Q3 & Q4

    • At the end of Q4, you will have a full year dataset


      Classes & Subclasses




      16


      Functionality was added to the software in version v.2013

  • Allow for better maintenance of the inventory of positions within the application


    Can be assigned to individual positions


  • Used to filter, sort, organize, and group items

    • In the Positions tab

    • On selected reports for better analysis


      The original classification menu has been modified to allow the user to define the available options to select

  • Previously only STAT to TAX and GAAP to STAT were available

  • Class for current positions

    • Default to GAAP to STAT or STAT to TAX

  • Subclass value for current positions

    • Default to GAAP to STAT-DEF or STAT to TAX-DEF


      Creating a new Class

  • In the Classes tab (in the Admin Center)

    • Select Classes from the Manage drop-down menu

    • Click Add


      Creating a new Class

  • A popup box will display

    • Enter a unique Code & Name for the new class

    • Click Save

  • A message will display at the top of the screen when new Classes are successfully created


    NOTE:

  • When a Class is created, a default Subclass is also automatically created and assigned to the Class

  • The newly created Subclass can be left “as is” or re-named

  • Additional Subclasses can be created and assigned to any Class


    Creating a new Subclass

  • In the Classes tab (in the Admin Center)

    • Select Subclasses from the Manage drop-down menu

      Add

    • Click


      Creating a new Subclass

  • A popup box will display

    • Enter a unique Code & Name for the new Subclass

    • Click Save

  • You will also have to assign the new Subclass to an existing class




  • Class & Subclass Names can be changed at any time

  • Class & Subclass Codes cannot be changed after being saved in the application

  • Classes & Subclasses can be deleted

    • Only when they are not in use



      Assigning Classes & Subclasses to uncertain tax positions takes place when creating a new position

  • In the regular WorkFlow (Positions tab)

  • Both fields require an entry

  • Classes cannot be changed, once a position is created

  • Subclasses can be changed at any time

    • Including after the dataset is rolled over




      Additional views have been added to selected reports to display Classes & SubClasses

  • Uncertain Payable Rollforward

  • Uncertain Deferred Rollforward

  • Deferred with Future Benefit Report



    Sign-Off Functionality




    29


    Users can access a new tab called Signoff upon request from the ONESOURCE Provision Technical Support Team



  • The sign off functionality allows preparers and reviewers to automatically notify the next level of review that they are finished updating the data on a particular unit. Some of the benefits are:

    • Improved process and governance support

    • Support for SOX compliance

    • Increased oversight over unit status


      Roles

  • When activated, the sign off feature creates new user roles:

    • Preparer

    • First Reviewer

    • Second Reviewer

    • Third Reviewer

    • Corporate


      Roles

  • The System administrator must assign the new Signoff Role to each user

  • Anywhere from 2 to 5 Signoff levels can be selected

    • Based on the users’ needs

  • Role names can be edited


    Questionnaires

  • Administrators will also have the ability to create questionnaires for each level of review

  • A new tab called Questionnaires will be available in the Admin Center when the functionality is activated



    Questionnaires

  • To create a questionnaire

    • Click on Add New

    • Enter a Code & Name

    • Select the dataset that it should apply to

    • Designate the level of review that it should be assigned to


      Questionnaires

  • There are three types of responses that can be set up for each question by the administrator

    • Yes/No

    • Short Text (<500 characters)

    • Long Text (>500 characters)


      Signoff Tab

  • After a preparer/reviewer has finished entering/reviewing their data for a unit, they can ‘commit’ it to the next level of review

    • Similarly, reviewers can ‘rollback’ a unit to the prior level of review or ‘revert’ it back to the preparer to make any changes.

  • Whenever any of these actions are performed

    • An automated e-mail will be sent to inform the next (commit) or prior (rollback) level reviewer

  • Users will not be able to commit, rollback, or revert a unit unless all of the questions in the questionnaire have been answered





    Reports

  • When the Signoff feature is activated, three additional reports will be made available:

    • Questionnaire Summary

      • Provides all answers to all of the questionnaires

    • Signoff Status Summary

      • Displays the review level of each unit

    • Signoff Workflow

      • Displays each user’s role for each unit


        Reports

  • Questionnaire Summary

  • Signoff Status Summary



  • Signoff Workflow



    Equity/Non-Cash Offsets




    41


    When adding a new position, the user has the option of marking it as an offset to

  • Equity

  • Non-Cash or

  • Income Statement

    • If neither EQ or NCS applies


      Once a position is rolled over, the user has the option to change the type of offset

  • Positions cannot be changed from NCS to EQ or EQ to NCS


    On Reports & Schedules

  • Uncertain Journal Entry and Calculation Support

    • Equity Positions

      • Tax & Other Tax amounts display in EQ: Equity Offset Line

      • Interest & Penalties amounts display in P/L: Provision for Current/Deferred Income Taxes

    • Non-Cash Positions

      • All amounts display in B/S: Non-Cash Offset Line

      • No amounts display in P/L: Provision for Current/ Deferred Income Taxes


        On Reports & Schedules

  • Uncertain Expense

    • Equity Positions

      • Only the Interest and Penalties amounts will display

    • Non-Cash Positions

      • No amounts will display


        On Reports & Schedules

  • Item Inventory

    • Equity Positions

      • Tax & Other Tax amounts display in Offset to Equity (Net) column

      • Interest & Penalties amounts display in Interest & Penalties columns

    • Non-Cash Positions

      • All amounts display in Offset to Non-Cash (Net) Column


        IMPACT TO PROVISION REPORT




        46


        Since version 2014.0, users can configure the application to define

  • How Uncertain Tax Positions are booked

  • How the results impact the Provision.


    GL Offset Codes can be established to define where positions are expected to settle based on the GL Offset type

  • Income Statement

  • Equity

  • Non-Cash


Perm, Temp & Tax Adjustment codes can be created in the Integration tab within the Admin Center

  • These codes can conform to similar codes within ONESOURCE Tax Provision




  • The GL offset codes created in the Admin Center can be assigned to individual positions in the position WorkFlow

    • These codes can be displayed next to each position in the Impact to Provision Report


Within the My UTP tab, there are additional settings that can be configured to dictate

  • How interest should be treated

    • Above the Line

    • Below the Line

  • Whether Fed benefit on state positions and Fed and State benefit on interest should be treated as

    • Current Expense

    • Deferred Expense




      Confidential and Proprietary


      A new report is available that displays how each position will impact the provision

      Confidential and Proprietary

  • Data from this report can be manually input into ONESOURCE Tax Provision based on the GL offset codes that are consistent between the two applications




HISTORIC (CUMULATIVE) CTA




53


Historic CTA functionality can be found in the Action Menu

  • After positions are modified in the current period, the Historic CTA can be updated when this action is selected

    • Current and deferred

    • Failure to trigger the update may cause an incorrect amount to post as the current year Historic CTA accrual.


      When Action Detail is selected, the following warning message will appear Click OK


      Select Execute Action to complete the Action



      By selecting this option in the Action Menu, the current year CTA adjustment required* will be calculated automatically by the UTP App

  • *The difference between beginning and current year ending spot rate applied to the beginning Accrual and/or Deferred balance.


    The resulting adjustment will automatically be populated in the Historic CTA Current/Deferred input field of the contingency workflow



    Alternatively, the current year change to the Historic CTA adjustment can be calculated offline and manually input into the same field (see images) of the contingency workflow.



    Note that in order for this computation to work correctly, it is mandatory that the FX rates are input in the system correctly

  • If the rates are incorrect, the computation could result in a current year CTA adjustment that is also incorrect


    Cumulative CTA can be viewed in both

  • The Uncertain Payable Rollforward Report and

  • The Uncertain Deferred Rollforward Report

    Dataset Combine

  • Use to merge two or more existing datasets together

  • Use cases

    • Multiple short year returns filed to compare to annual provision for return to provision posting

    • Periodic datasets (monthly or quarterly) for provision to compare to annual return filing

      Reporting Datasets

  • Additive

    • Used to layer on activity for the same time period

  • Sequential

    • Used to report on periodic datasets and see the aggregated amounts


      When adding a dataset, choose combine from the transaction dropdown to continue through the 3 step process.

      Select datasets to combine from existing datasets and decide on access.


      The new Reporting Dataset is available in the Reporting menu with the Type of Additive or Sequential identified


      Allows for one update and cascades to all units upon trigger with flexibility to override to alternate value for exception units

  • Country Rates

    • If multiple units exist within the same country and federal tax rates change

    • i.e. the US tax rate change for 2018

  • Currency Rates

    • If multiple units use the same currency and would have the same ending spot rates

    • i.e. units using Euro

  • State Rates

    • If multiple units are filing in the same state and state rates change


      Updates are performed in the Administration menu so any dataset can benefit from the most current rates, while maintaining historical rates at the dataset level in older datasets



      Activate parameter: CountryRates CurrencyRates StateRates

      In Dataset Parameters option with an Alphanumeric type a value of Y



      If units are already activated in a dataset, then the existing rates will be considered overrides. When activating a new unit it will use the rate in the dataset administration screen based on the country and currency the unit is assigned to. For state rates it is based on the states activated for a particular unit.


      Automatically modifies the federal treatment of a book/tax difference to cascade to each state based on a percentage

  • Universal setting for all states can be set by using “All” or “None” options

  • “Custom” option to choose which states need modified

    • Copy allows you model after another difference

    • Percentage indicates how much of the federal amount is accepted by the state


Updates are performed in the Administration menu so any dataset can benefit from the most state treatment, while maintaining historical rules at the dataset level in older datasets

Choose custom to specify setting by state

Copy From selection & Copy inherits from another difference

    Exclude non-cash component of state current tax expense from federal deduction

    • No allows you to tie exactly to total current state tax expense

    • Yes allows you to exclude items like state UTPs, RTPs, and tax audit adjustments which can allow you to align the federal deduction more closely to your ultimate filing position for the current tax year


Yes

  • Total differential is for pre-tax income related only


    No

  • Total differential is permanent differences and pre-tax income related



    Assign classes relating to GAAP only items

    • Should include system class RTP_GAAP

      Enable GAAP-STAT Scrunch

    • Identified GAAP only classes will not be combined with all other classes upon rollover

      Post GAAP to STAT RTP

    • Return to provision will post with class RTP and subclass GAAP or STAT depending on if the difference is on an identified GAAP class or not

DP171 - Valuation Allowance Complications Under Tax Reform: Simplify with ONESOURCE Tax Provision® 2016 & ONESOURCE Workpapers®

November 2018 BDO USA, LLP


1


Ben is a Partner in BDO’s Core Tax Services practice in Los Angeles. He has been with BDO for the past 4 ½ years and opened the Las Vegas tax practice prior to his move. He is also a member of the national ASC 740 practice.

Prior to BDO, Ben specialized in income tax process, technology and technical issues with the Big Four for over 17 years.

Ben received his Bachelor of Science and Masters of Accountancy from Miami University in Oxford, Ohio. He is a certified public accountant in California, Nevada and Ohio.

Matt is a manager in BDO’s Core Tax Services practice in Detroit. He has been with BDO for the past 6 ½ years.

Matt’s experience includes tax compliance, focusing on corporation and partnership taxation, ASC 740 and tax consulting, including transaction structuring, partnership termination and due diligence merger & acquisition advising.

Objectives

Upon completion, attendees will be able to recognize specific areas of Tax Reform that affect the valuation allowance, identify how to apply specific areas of Tax Reform to the valuation allowance analysis and determine how utilizing OTP v.2016 and Workpapers can simplify the valuation allowance analysis.


Session Abstract


Explore the changes to the valuation allowance analysis under Tax Reform and the ways we are simplifying this analysis by using ONESOURCE Tax Provision® v.2016 and ONESOURCE Workpapers®


3 Key Session Take Aways


  • Gain a better understanding of specific areas of Tax Reform that affect the valuation allowance including net operating losses and interest deduction limitations


  • Learn how to apply specific areas of Tax Reform to the valuation allowance analysis


  • Understand how we are utilizing ONESOURCE Tax Provision® v.2016 and ONESOURCE Workpapers to simplify the valuation allowance analysis


    4:15 Valuation Allowance Refresher

    4:30 Changes to the Valuation Allowance Analysis due to Tax Reform

    5:00 How to utilize ONESOURCE Tax Provision® and ONESOURCE Workpapers® in the analysis


    Realization of tax benefits of deductible temporary differences and carryovers is dependent upon an entity having:

  • Sufficient taxable income

    • Of an appropriate character (e.g. ordinary vs. capital)

    • Within the statutory carryback/carryforward period


      ASC 740-10-30-18 provides four possible sources of taxable income that should be considered to realize a tax benefit for deductible temporary differences and/or tax attributes:

  • Future reversal of existing taxable temporary differences

  • Expected future taxable income exclusive of reversing temporary differences and carryforwards

  • Taxable income in prior carryback years

  • Tax-planning strategies


    Confidential and Proprietary


    All available positive and negative evidence must be considered

  • Evidence will include both objective and subjective information

    Source #1 and #3 can be “objectively verified” as they represent the financial accounting/tax consequences of past transactions

    Source #2 and #4 are “subjective” as they represent future events

  • Weight given to evidence should be commensurate with the extent to which it can be objectively verified




    Confidential and Proprietary

    9


    Examples of Negative Evidence

  • Cumulative losses in recent years

  • History of expired carryforwards

  • Short carryforward / carryback periods

  • General industry trends

  • Going concern issues

  • No taxable income expected in future years

    Examples of Positive Evidence

  • Positive earnings history

  • No history of expired carryforwards

  • Long or unlimited carryforward periods

  • Sales backlog

  • Appreciated net asset values


    Confidential and Proprietary


  • Significant piece of negative evidence that is difficult to overcome


  • There is a presumption that a valuation allowance is needed if cumulative book losses in recent years

    • Presumption may be overcome


  • Not specifically defined in ASC 740


  • Common practice

    • Pre-tax book loss

    • Recent years = current tax year and prior two tax years (rolling 12 quarters)


      Confidential and Proprietary

      11


  • Weight given to evidence is commensurate with the degree to which it can be objectively verified


  • Cannot objectively verify a forecast


  • Forecasts generally will not overcome substantial negative evidence (i.e. cumulative book losses in recent years)


    Confidential and Proprietary


  • Need for valuation allowance must often be determined separately for each jurisdiction due to differing carryback/carryover rules


  • Even within a single jurisdiction, need for valuation allowance with respect to different types of carryovers must often be evaluated individually due to different carryback/carryover periods and differing limitations on utilization


  • Balance sheet impact of valuation allowance

    • Decreases amount of deferred tax asset

    • Under ASU 2015-17, all deferred taxes are recorded as non-current net of any valuation allowances on a jurisdictional basis


  • Income statement impact of valuation allowance

    • Increase in valuation allowance—generally increased tax expense/decreased net book income

    • Decrease in valuation allowance—generally decreased tax expense/increased net book income


  • Scheduling – offsetting deductible and taxable temporary differences


  • Scheduling is not expressly required by ASC 740

    • Often necessary to ensure proper matching of reversals


  • Objective in selecting a method is to minimize complexity


  • Method should be:

    • Systematic and logical

    • Same method for each category (regardless of jurisdiction)

    • Applied consistently from year to year


      Consider the following when determining reversal patterns:


  • Carryforward and carryback periods


  • Character of the taxable and deductible amounts

    • Ordinary income vs. capital gain


  • Indefinite reversals

    • Tax-deductible goodwill, indefinite lived intangible assets, US federal net operating loss carryforwards generated after December 31, 2017 and non-deductible interest expense occurring after December 31, 2017


      Scheduling future taxable income

  • Objective evidence

  • Assume breakeven for book purposes

  • Reversal of temporary difference without assuming originating differences

  • Carryover and carryback considered

  • Pattern of reversals needs to be considered

  • Can be extremely technical

  • Be cognizant of indefinite lived deferred tax items in jurisdictions with finite carryover periods

  • Apply tax law to scheduling exercise

    “Naked Credits”


  • DTLs resulting from temporary differences that can be offset by the existing reversing deductible temporary differences, NOLs or credits, may be considered a source of income to eliminate or reduce the need for a VA

    • Companies often net DTLs against DTAs to compute VA (this is scheduling)

    • Indefinite-lived intangibles and goodwill are not amortized

    • DTL’s on indefinite lived intangibles often create a “Naked Credit”


  • DTLs from indefinite-lived intangibles can only be used as a source of income to offset DTAs with indefinite lives when computing VA

    • The offset of indefinite lived NOLs can only be 80% of the indefinite lived DTLs due to the limitation on the use of indefinite lived NOLs

    • The offset of indefinite lived interest limitation DTAs can only be 30% of indefinite lived DTLs due to the limitation on the deductibility of interest expense

    • You must consider the interest limitation offset first and how it will effect the NOL limitation offset


  • Naked credits

  • IRC §382 and §383 limitations

  • Short amortization period for intangibles with longer lived deferred tax assets

  • Different carryforward periods for pre-2018 and post-2017 US federal NOLs

  • Limitations on NOL usage for countries even with infinite carryover periods (e.g. Germany and US)

  • Different group utilization rules for current year losses and NOL carryforwards (e.g. United Kingdom)


  • Tax-planning strategies will accelerate or create income so that the company can take advantage of future deductible differences


  • Tax-planning strategies must be prudent and feasible


  • Management must have ability and intent to implement although actual implementation is not required


  • Search is not optional

    Examples


  • Sale – leaseback of appreciated assets

  • Changing inventory methods

  • Electing out of installment sales method

  • Election to capitalize R&D costs

  • Merging or liquidating subsidiaries

  • Electing an alternate depreciation system

  • Base shifting/transfer pricing


    Certain events not within management’s control cannot be factored into analysis:

  • Anticipated changes in tax laws and rates or tax status

  • Sale of “held-to-maturity” securities

  • Sales of indefinite-life intangible assets

  • Changes in fair value of assets and liabilities

  • Events dependent upon future market conditions

  • Future business combinations

  • Expected forgiveness of debt (actual forgiveness?)


  • Stock options

  • IRC §382 and §383 limitations

  • State carryforwards

  • Alternative minimum tax (pre-2018)

  • Foreign tax credits

  • Future credits

  • Going concern opinion

  • Deferred effects of intercompany transactions


  • Advantages of using Microsoft Excel® to calculate valuation allowances

    • Provides for vast flexibility and customization

    • Allows certain users to utilize accounting systems such as Oracle Hyperion® to pull in data to complete valuation allowance analysis

    • Most users are familiar and comfortable with excel


  • Limitations of using Microsoft Excel® to calculate valuation allowances

    • Requires user to input valuation allowance amounts into ONESOURCE Tax Provision® manually which presents risk

    • Requires changes to Microsoft Excel® schedules every time the books change or provision is updated

    • Microsoft Excel® provides no version control, risk with formula errors, etc.


  • ONESOURCE Tax Provision® offers automation of the valuation allowance


  • This feature can be turned on/off in the Manage Units section for each unit under the “Other Tab”



  • Advantages of using the built-in valuation allowance automation feature

    • Can set valuation allowance rates for specific types (NOL, after-tax, temps)

    • Can set units by unit for jurisdictional specific toggling (e.g., US only, foreign only, etc.)

    • Automation ensures that the valuation allowance is always being applied and updated instantaneously as you make changes


  • Limitations of using the built-in valuation allowance automation feature

    • Cannot account for naked credits (all or none)

    • Cannot automate specific state by state valuation allowance needs (all or none)

    • Does not allow for automation of deferred scheduling and automated updates to valuation allowance


  • Is there a way to combine Microsoft Excel® and automation?


  • ONESOURCE Workpapers® offers users the ability to create excel schedules that can push and pull data from the tax provision to help with valuation allowance analysis and computation


  • ONESOURCE Workpapers® can integrate existing proprietary spreadsheets like those containing tax specific computations such as depreciation, tax credit computations and in our case scheduling of deferreds and losses


  • ONESOURCE Workpapers® can be setup to pull data directly from ONESOURCE Tax Provision® that can be used in analysis and calculations


  • Consider ways that you can use ONESOURCE Workpapers® to pull in deferred balance, federal, foreign and state net operating loss balances, tax credit balances, etc. to use in your valuation allowance analysis


  • Users can load in forecasting for pre-tax book income on a jurisdictional basis or other relevant information to use in the analysis


  • ONESOURCE Workpapers® functions just like excel so create the necessary formulas and once the calculation is done, ONESOURCE Workpapers® can push the results directly back to ONESOURCE Tax Provision® for seamless automation in real time


    Confidential and Proprietary

    29


  • Advantages of using ONESOURCE Workpapers® for valuation allowance automation

    • Can utilize ONESOURCE Tax Provision® data, internal data, etc. to create flexible and sensible schedules that will ensure the proper analysis is done with ease

    • Once these workpapers are setup they can be rolled forward to new datasets, updated for maintenance items and utilized year over year

    • Data is pulled directly from ONESOURCE Tax Provision®, ensuring no errors in data input and constant updating

    • Workpapers automation ensures that the valuation allowance is automatically applied and updated instantaneously as you make changes


  • Limitations of using ONESOURCE Workpapers® for valuation allowance automation

    • Initial setup time and training

    • Continue to watch for formula errors and changes (audit trail)



Confidential and Proprietary

DP174 - Role of Small Automation in Tax Functions – easier to implement and increases productivity

Objectives

Upon successful completion attendees will be able to identify benefits of small automation projects for productivity gains, the differences in a small automation approach that enable process improvements and recognize areas where small automation is faster with more immediate impact.


The objectives of this session are:

  • Evaluate the benefit of “small” automation projects by choosing fast implementation of flexible and adaptable technologies that fill the gaps left by your current systems, thus enabling new levels of productivity.

  • Begin to identify the differences a small automation approach from big automation that can enable process improvements, while being easier to implement and less expensive.

  • Recognize areas where small automation can have a faster, more immediate impact, whereas big automation gains and results could be far off into the future due to lack of standardized process and/or variable data sources.


    Tax Function of the Future series

Small automation


  • For Tax, it means fast implementation of flexible and adaptable technologies


  • Builds upon foundation of existing enterprise technology and tax technology solutions


  • Achieved by the use of self-service solutions


  • Driven by and for the end-user


  • Allows for targeting of individual processes or tasks


  • Does not depend on standardization


  • Can be scaled and integrated over time


    Consider the future of work: New way of working – leaders will have to ensure everyone’s mind-set will shift accordingly


    • Automation tools can include self-service and those managed at enterprise level


    • Three types of self-service tools driving small automation in Tax today:


      • Extract, Transform and Load (ETL)

        • Integrate data from disparate sources


      • Robotics (RDA and RPA)

        • Coded software to perform rule-based processes; mimics interactions of users


      • Analytics and data visualization

        • Dynamic/interactive dashboard displays


Is your Tax function considering emerging self-service automation solutions?


  1. Yes, we are already using automation tools such as RPA (robotics process automation) and ETL (extract, transform, and load)

  2. We are piloting an initiative with these tools, but not using the tools ‘live’ yet in our department

  3. We are considering, but need more information to get started

  4. No, we are not considering using these tools today

    Five factors to reimagine automation for Tax



    Business processes: Your people reimagining work

    Questions to ask


    • Where are the pain points and low-value mechanical hours being spent? Have you done a current state inventory/analysis of your processes?


      Start with analyzing end-to-end processes or with discrete tasks, within one or multiple functions


      Evaluate how people are spending their time – too much time spent on data manipulation?


    • What is on the ‘wish’ list?


      Think big – imagine how time-consuming and mundane activities should be tackled

      Practical tips from leading companies


      Choose the right processes to automate

      • Pinpoint those with a high return and fewer barriers for success

      • Pain points should serve as a roadmap

      • Do not avoid cross functional tasks – their automation can bring wider enterprise value

      • Does not have to be ‘all’ or none – 80/20 rule


Focusing first on short-term value

  • Demonstrate strong returns in a short period , i.e., start realizing benefits quickly


Redefine the process with technology in mind


Automation tools: Core functionality


What can the tools do to drive efficiency and solve problems?


  • Process large data sets

  • Reconcile data

  • Integrate and transfer data between systems

  • Display variety of data points/ measures

  • Enable collaboration with data-sharing

  • Access data in a centralized location

  • Create ad hoc reports and queries

  • Mimic repeatable human behavior


  • Basically ANYTHING mechanical or rules- based (even if rules are ‘fuzzy’)

Source data extraction, cleansing, and integration into existing models (e.g., tax reform data integration, R&D )


Sample tasks ripe for automation


Complex data transformation and computations (discrete calculations; look for networks of complex spreadsheets)


Aggregate, analyze, reconcile, compare, validate data (trend and exception analysis)


Data entry / upload into or between systems (e.g., entry of data into tax software)


Questions to ask


  • How can self-service automation empower our individuals?


    Enable significant time savings for specific tasks


  • Who should be involved in the planning and implementation stage?


    Most notably, end-users should drive the process


  • What reskilling will need to occur once automation is integrated into the process?


    Tax staff must embrace technology know-how


    Practical tips from leading companies


  • Communicate and be transparent


    • Senior executives may want to deliver the core message that humans – not machines – are the key to optimizing automation


    • Individuals want to feel secure about their jobs and that they are integral to the team


  • Promote a ‘change mindset’ by focusing on the benefits team members will experience


  • Hold end-users accountable for success


  • Market success stories internally



Questions to ask


  • How are processes supported and monitored, during implementation and after go-live?


    Systems must be maintained going forward – roles and responsibilities should be identified

  • What stakeholders and regulatory requirements will be impacted?

    Examples: SOX, IA, External auditors; other issues include IT security and access controls

  • How and where will new processes be documented?

    Adding to existing policies may be simple solution


    Practical tips from leading companies


  • Balance culture of experimentation and innovation versus best practice sharing, quality standards, and consistency


  • Identify when strict governance should begin


    • Day one versus post-testing, i.e., after end-users provide input during a pilot stage


  • Evaluate both centralized management practices and end-user guidelines


  • Consider a cross-functional automation ‘center of excellence’ or ‘technology council’


    • Include business users, technology SMEs, and IT

    • Establish mechanism to share best practice stories

An overview of robotic process automation (RPA)


RPA is integrated into existing IT infrastructure.

RPA is a computer software that runs repetitive, rule-based

RPA is software.

processes. The software is trained based on functional specifications and can be adjusted at any time.

RPA simulates an employee.

The software robot has access to diverse applications with an ID or a password. The robot can gather information or change data. Consequently, business and administrative processes can be fully automated.

What is robotic process automation (RPA)?




Robotic process automation (RPA) is the application of software that mimics human actions and connects multiple fragmented systems and business processes together through automation

Robotic process automation (RPA)

A software solution that runs unattended, working like a virtual employee with legacy applications performing repetitive tasks reliably at the User Interface level

Current workforce
